attributes.action: Increase funding for public transport to make it cheaper than private transport
attributes.background: Public transportation is often more expensive than private cars. This does not make sense and within the context of global warming and too much pollution which is damaging people’s health. In order to reduce the number of cars on the road the Government should make public transport cheaper.
attributes.additional_details: There are too many private vehicles on the roads, increasing co2 levels and pollution. The price of public transport, and especially trains, means it is often not affordable to many people, leaving those who need them most unable to access public transport. The Government should increase funding for public transport so that this becomes cheaper than private transport, and more accessible to all irrespective of income.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban Horses From Public Roads
attributes.background: Humans haven't needed horses to travel or to move goods for over 100 years, and nowadays the roads are so busy that they have not only become a hazard, but they disrupt modern transport routes.
attributes.additional_details:
I believe horses are an out of date mode of transport and their use is no longer fit for purpose.
 
Horses are not only a hazard, but they cause traffic to slow down, fuelling congestion. It's also cruel to subject the animals to both pollution and the scary sound of cars.
 
The British Horse Society statistics show that from Nov 2010 to Mar 2019 there were 3,737 incidents reported. 315 horses and 43 humans were killed on our roads. The use of horses should be limited to private property, either entirely or at least during peak traffic times.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Create a law that requires unnecessary lighting to be turned off
attributes.background: Create a law that requires lights in shop window displays to be turned off at 1am. Interior lights in offices and other non-residential buildings should be switched off an hour after the last employee leaves.
attributes.additional_details: The impact will be to save wasted energy and reduce the impact of light pollution in the country, all of which damages wildlife, humans and the environment.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Impose a blanket ban on deep sea mining
attributes.background: Impose a blanket ban on all deep sea mining by the UK, to ensure our country has no part to play in exploiting our oceans.
attributes.additional_details:
Deep sea mining has the potential to cause untold damage and potential destruction to pristine, undisturbed eco-systems.
 
The physical reality of drilling will lead to vast plumes of thick sediment being released over fragile and beautiful eco-systems while these same eco-systems would endure noise pollution which could affect sea animals’ ability to communicate with each other.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Subsidise the conversion of Euro 5 diesel engines to Euro 6.
attributes.background: Clean Air Zones & ULEZ expansion will reduce pollution. However, many lower-income people suddenly face huge daily running costs & devaluation of their vehicle.
attributes.additional_details:
We call on the government to support them by subsidising Euro 6 retrofits. This would benefit those on low income & British business.
 
We support the pollution-reduction aims of Clean Air Zones and ULEZ expansion.
 
However, the speed with which these policies have been introduced has disproportionately affected lower-income people.
 
UK-based businesses can retro-fit older vehicles to meet Euro 6 standards.
 
However, the cost is prohibitive for many people.
 
Subsidising this would benefit those on low incomes, British business, and reduce opposition to further environmental policy revisions.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Impose a corporation tax surcharge on companies that produce single-use plastics
attributes.background: Impose a corporation tax surcharge on companies that produce single-use plastics, based on the cost of removing plastic waste from the environment. The worst offenders would pay the highest surcharges, which would act as an incentive to change their behaviour.
attributes.additional_details: Every year billions of single-use plastic bottles and plastic packaging are bought across the UK, most ending up in landfill sites and in the oceans, causing damage to wildlife and resulting in microplastics that pollute the food chain. It can take upwards of 450 years for a single plastic bottle to degrade and so the problem is one that is going to affect future generations. It’s about time the Government took this problem seriously and showed they are serious about sustainability.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Ban plastic bags illegal and require the use of biodegradable bags instead
attributes.background:
We must pay 5p per general-sized bag. From 1 April this goes up to 10p per bag. Our modern lifestyle means many people are 'impromptu shoppers', and usually have no issue spending 5p. 
Italy introduced biodegradable 'plastic' bags in 2011 and charge less than 5p per bag. Plastic pollutes our planet
attributes.additional_details:
Biodegradable 'plastic' bags have been in use in Italy since 2011 with great success, they don't pollute the environment, which I think as a responsible citizen of this planet we should all be striving to improve on.

I hope that you will all give this serious consideration.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Create a ‘Day of Rest’ in each calendar week as we come out lockdown.
attributes.background: The lockdown has proved that we as a nation can not only survive but also thrive when we’re forced to Slow down and bring about a natural pause or stop in our busy lives. The environment and wild animal species have been allowed in many respects to return to ‘their normal’ as pollution levels drop.
attributes.additional_details:
To return to having a day of rest where planes, trains and transport systems were halted for 24hrs, where businesses and schools  re charged through ‘stopping’ and allowed employees and pupils to rejuvenate or work from home.
Carbon emissions targets would surely be more obtainable.
This doesn’t have to be based on the old model of a religious day of rest, but of course those who wish to return to still contemplation and prayer could do so. It would be more powerful as an international movement.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Ban All Commercial Flights On Sundays
attributes.background: Take the lessons learnt from the inflicted global shutdown to benefit the planet and prevent further global warming and pollution by banning all commercial flying on Sundays.
attributes.additional_details:
The Coronavirus is a global tragedy, on all levels personal, social and economically.  However, we are already seeing the incredible benefits to the environment. 

What mustn't happen is for Covid-19 to come, kill, destroy and leave without us learning from the tragedies that have occurred. Lets recognise the benefits of global shutdown on the environment, how it's helping heal our world and make changes for the better.  One day a week of no commercial flying would allow the planet to breathe.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Make new Public transport manufactured after 2030 electric.
attributes.background: The government should legislate to not only end the sale of new diesel and petrol cars by 2030 but should also ensure new public transport does not run-on diesel or petrol by the same date.
attributes.additional_details: Buses also create almost a kilogram of CO2 pollution every kilometre (860g / Km). TfL in 2018 - 19 had 455.2 Million miles of bus routes planned of which 98.36% of those were completed. That resulted in 391.472 million kilograms of CO2 pollution to enter into the air in just one year and the UK should seek to lead the world in green public transport. Electric buses by 2030 would be a considerable objective to aim towards.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban wood and garden waste burning.
attributes.background: We call on the Government to ban the burning of wood and garden waste in residential areas. We want to enjoy clean air in the summer and wintertime.
attributes.additional_details:
Wood burning is the largest contributor to wintertime pollution (Particulate matter pollution - PM2.5) and an increase in PM2.5 levels can result in increases death rates as the quality of the air is made worse.

We need to change our attitudes towards wood burning. We cannot afford to regard the smell of wood smoke as something evocative, nostalgic, or natural. Science is not subject to debate, burning wood and garden waste is shortening lives.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Impose a levy on all plastic production in the UK
attributes.background: I want the Government to impose a levy on plastic production to cover the cost of tidying our land and sea of the unsightliness and dangers of plastic pollution. Our bodies, wildlife, waterways, towns and countryside are awash with non-recyclable, non-biodegradable plastic and plastic particles.
attributes.additional_details: Evidence shows that plastics are not easily reusable or recyclable or biodegradable. A levy is needed to pay for the damage and mess of plastic pollution and incentivise producers to move to more sustainable practices. The amount imposed needs to be enough to mount a demonstrably effective and ongoing clean-up operation, and act as a financial disincentive to continued production.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Hold COBR meetings to address the climate emergency
attributes.background: The House of Commons declared a climate emergency. COBR meetings must be held to deal with the national crisis and catastrophic disruption it will bring for people, nature, society, and environment. Action is needed now to deal with the crisis to stop fossil fuels and protect/restore nature.
attributes.additional_details: Greenhouse gases are pouring into the atmosphere at catastrophic rates and action is needed now. Current ambition is not enough. We depend on nature, but are destroying it at an alarming rate and it is in crisis. Pollution is engulfing the planet, but polluters are not paying for destruction. Current Committees are not acting at sufficient pace, or influencing action as an emergency! New plans with innovators, entrepreneurs, financiers, environmentalists, are needed to transform to a circular economy.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Ban all advertising of carbon-emitting SUVs in the UK
attributes.background: The extraordinary growth of carbon-emitting SUVs has contributed hugely to global car emissions (almost entirely cancelling out carbon gains made by the growth of Electric Vehicles) and these cars add to poor air quality that studies show kills tens of thousands each year.
attributes.additional_details:
Cigarette ads are rightly banned, and there is no reason why car manufacturers should be allowed to continue to promote carbon-emitting and polluting SUVs.

In 1965, amidst growing concern over the impacts that smoking had on health, advertising cigarettes on TV was banned in the UK. By 2005 all promotion had been banned, and smoking has declined as a result. Yet we still allow car manufacturers to promote carbon-emitting SUVs that impact air quality and contribute to carbon emissions. Why? In line with sensible precedent on banning advertising to drive down smoking, this government should ban all promotions of SUVs.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Ban the advertising and endorsement of Internal Combustion Engine Vehicles.
attributes.background:
The advertising of Internal Combustion Engines should be banned.
 
This should include a ban on "endorsement" – meaning a company/organisation/business/celebrity/other cannot sponsor/advertise or put its/their name/logo on a vehicle with an Internal Combustion Engine.
attributes.additional_details:
Pollutants from Internal combustion engines (petrol/diesel vehicles) on your country’s roads are having detrimental effects on your health and those around you.

Help stop glorifying that which kills men, women and children every year!

One step closer towards a cleaner, greener, more sustainable future!
See also; Clean Air Strategy 2019 

Advertising only for alternatively fuelled, zero emission vehicles of all types/modes of transport.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban plastic and foil balloon releases and fund memorial forests instead
attributes.background: Thousands of balloons are released into the towns & countryside of the UK every year..
attributes.additional_details:
These balloons pollute, can endanger farm animals, and do not decompose. They serve zero purpose in assisting the environment and it goes without saying that despite sentimental intention they can actually cause harm.

If the Government funded the planting of trees in memory of loved ones, perhaps people would have memorial forests to visit during their own lifetimes instead of two minutes of a balloon release and nothing to show for it.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the advertisement of plastic and non-recyclable toys to children
attributes.background: Regulate which kinds of products can be advertised directly to children (e.g. during kids TV Ad Breaks) to ensure that items made from plastic and non-recyclable materials are not advertised to children.
attributes.additional_details: Plastics are a major part of climate crisis. They can take thousands of years to break down, polluting our environment especially our oceans. When we are actively trying to move towards a greener & more sustainable society it makes no sense to continue heavily promoting plastic toys to our children. If these ads were banned there would be an incentive for this industry to use more sustainable alternatives to produce their products & packaging, the next generation should be encouraged away from plastic.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban cigarettes - The Largest Ocean Polluter
attributes.background: In April 2021 England will officially ban the single use plastics such as straws and cotton buds. Wales will also do the same in Spring 2021. However the largest source of single use plastic pollution is cigarettes. Therefore it would be appropriate to also ban cigarettes.
attributes.additional_details: The Government have agreed to ban single use plastic in 2021, however the list of items banned crucially misses out cigarettes. Cigarettes are the top single use plastic polluter in the world! On top of the plastic and microplastics issue, cigarettes also add harmful chemicals such as nicotine, lead and arsenic into the environment. These chemicals enter our food chain leading to bioaccumulation. They have also been shown to inhibit plant growth on land and reduce crop yeilds.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale and use of all cigarettes (including e-cigarettes) by 2030.
attributes.background:
Each year, thousands of patients are forced to wait longer for treatment as the NHS deals with smoking related issues.

As well as immeasurable strain on our NHS, communities and children across the country are forced to deal with the intrusive social pollution of cigarette smoke and litter.
attributes.additional_details:
In a 2018 report by the UK government it states "smoking remains our biggest preventable killer. In England alone, 78,000 people a year - or 200 per day - die from smoking. In addition to the human cost, smoking costs the economy £14.7 billion per year, £2.5 billion of which falls to the NHS."

Making smoking socially unacceptable alone will not be sufficient to stop the impact on the rest of our country.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Provide funding for active travel and road safety improvements near schools
attributes.background: I believe that local authorities should get more funding for road improvements that would make areas around schools safer, and to make it easier for students to walk or cycle to school
attributes.additional_details: If the Government provided funding for road improvements around schools, this could help children be more active, and reduce pollution around schools.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Reform legislation that allows plastics to go undeclared on textile labels
attributes.background: The Government should require the full disclosure of all fossil fuel derived plastics in textiles and clothing.
attributes.additional_details:
The Textile Products Regulations allows some parts, which often contain fossil fuel derived materials, to not be listed on composition labels in clothing and textile products.
 
Plastic production from fossil fuels for synthetic fibres is increasing. Fossil fuel extraction is the primary cause of our climate crisis. Recycling is not a solution.
 
We believe incomplete labelling of textile products is a silent contributor to the catastrophe of global warming and plastic and microplastic pollution that’s devastating our ecosystems. Obscuring the full facts denies UK citizens the choice of reducing their plastic footprint.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Require greenery to be added to highways with unused space to combat pollution
attributes.background: Highways England should be required to plant more greenery around, or in the middle of, highways with available space. The RHS has found that Cotoneaster is at least 20% more effective than other shrubs at reducing pollution. Alternatives could also be considered.
attributes.additional_details: With coronavirus restrictions lessening, the common trend shows that cars will begin to return to the roads, increasing the surrounding pollution. The problem of air pollution has been worked on in some areas, especially in London with the Ultra-Low Emission Zone. However, more could be done on roadsides. Some highways have vast amounts of empty space that could be filled with greenery.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban the sale of petrol powered garden tools to encourage shift to alternatives
attributes.background: With the world in the grips of an environmental crisis there is absolutely no excuse for the continued use of garden tools that pollute the atmosphere with chemicals and noise, damage people's health, and perpetuate our reliance on fossil fuels.
attributes.additional_details:
Petrol machinery produces airborne pollution that can impair breathing & aggravate existing heart & lung conditions.
 
The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has estimated that a lawnmower can produce the same air pollution as 11 cars. A Swedish study has also found that the emissions from a petrol mower used for one hour are equivalent to those released by a car on a 100-mile journey.
 
A ban on the sale of petrol powered garden tools would encourage a shift to battery powered garden tools. This should improve air quality and could help tackle global warming.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Nationalise water companies
attributes.background: Nationalise water companies and invest in improving the antiquated infrastructure,  particularly the sewage system.  Protect our waterways and reservoirs and lakes and ensure that they are in good ecological condition and safe for people to use and enjoy.
attributes.additional_details: Water companies are placing profit before protecting the environment.  Last year 1.5m hours of raw sewage were pumped into English rivers. Action is not being taken to prevent our waterways being polluted. Part of the problem is a sewage system which does not seem to be fit for purpose. If water was back in public ownership it would be easier to ensure that rivers were not being polluted  and would also help to mitigate against flooding.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund free public transport for all
attributes.background: Luxembourg has made almost all public transport free to reduce air pollution, congestion and greenhouse gases. It could also help improve the health of the general public. It's paid for out of taxes. We want the UK Government to take the same action, particularly now petrol is so expensive.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban all non-biodegradable chewing gum
attributes.background: Non-biodegradable chewing gum causes significant environmental damage. Therefore, the Government should enact a law that bans all production and selling of non-biodegradable gum in the UK.
attributes.additional_details: The main issue with non-biodegradable gum is that it is often not discarded properly. For public authorities this is a huge challenge causing tremendous strain on the public purse. The Local Government Association has estimated that for each piece of gum costing 3p the cost of removal is £1.50 which adds up to £60 million bill annually for local authorities. Moreover, gum can flow into water streams and pollutes oceans and rivers leading to many animals and sea life ingesting it.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase road tax when more than two vehicles are registered to the same address
attributes.background: To ease Parking on our roads we need to take action to reduce Vehicles and the Parking they cause. Fire Services have had issues getting down roads, there is NO need for Everyone to have a Vehicle, it adds Pollution and Climate Charge, we need to free up our Roads getting Gridlocked.
attributes.additional_details:
To tackle Asthma Issues from poor air quality. Congestion it getting worse as above, makes people Lazy. It’s much too Cheap to stick a Vehicle on the Road. We have one car for Two and it works perfectly,
 
Unclog our Roads.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Legalise and incentivise uptake of personal electric vehicles
attributes.background: I would like the Government to legalise and create incentives to promote uptake of all personal, micro powered, more carbon efficient vehicles. This could help reduce carbon emissions from personal transport.
attributes.additional_details: This is an issue that requires swift action to take a global lead in changing travel behaviours. Both for global environment and local pollution. The costs of this damage are on record. And in the current fuel and cost of living crisis, many lives could be improved and cities made less polluted and provided with a more mobile work force. We believe the environmental, social and commercial benefits are clear.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Expand Highway Code relating to the running of engines of parked vehicles
attributes.background: Expand Highway Code Rule 123 "You must not leave a vehicle's engine running unnecessarily while that vehicle is stationary on a public road", to apply to all roads & open spaces inc. car parks, irrespective of whether they are public or private. National advertising campaign to educate the public.
attributes.additional_details: The law currently prohibits ‘vehicle idling’ but expanding the Highway Code and a public awareness campaign could help reduce damaging emissions and improve public health. It is common practice for car drivers to park up with their engines running e.g. when taking phone calls, waiting in drop off zones (hospitals, railway stations, schools), delivery drivers, etc. Private roads & spaces to be included as the air polluted at these sites is NOT PRIVATELY OWNED and should not be regarded as such.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Make cycle lane use mandatory for bicycles where safe cycle lanes are provided
attributes.background:
Make the use of cycle lanes mandatory for all bicycles, electric bicycles and push scooters where cycle lanes are provided (this includes pop up cycle lanes)

Cyclists who fail to use provided lanes put themselves at increased risk of injury, and litigation by riding in traffic &having an accident
attributes.additional_details:
All over the country local authorities are investing millions in creating new cycling infrastructure both to encourage safe riding & reduce pollution as a result of increased cycle uptake and reduced car use

Some cyclists do not use cycle lanes where provided. This increases their risk of being involved in a serious or fatal incident with a vehicle & also increases claims against motorists regardless of fault

Making cycle lanes mandatory could reduce the number of injuries & fatalities on the road

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Fund organic food production to reduce cost
attributes.background: Organic food is more expensive than non-organic food. This means that only richer people can afford to eat healthy organic food. In order to increase health and sustainable practices the Government should make organic food cheaper.
attributes.additional_details:
Non-organics use pesticides which are environmental pollutants, use fertilizers (polluting water systems) and degrade top soil. 
 
Agroecology and organic food production do the opposite.
 
The Government should increase funding for organic food production, so that this becomes cheaper than non-organics, and more accessible to all irrespective of income.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Legalise Natural Organic Reduction
attributes.background: Natural organic reduction - AKA human composting - is an ecologically friendly alternative to cremation. The deceased is covered in plant matter and then placed in a chamber to compost for 1-2 months. Afterwards, the compost can be used for growing plants. I would like the government to legalise it.
attributes.additional_details: Natural organic reduction is not natural burial - it is much faster (< 1yr, vs natural burial's 8-12yrs) and the nutrient-rich compost can be used anywhere. This could be of great benefit to areas in the UK where the soil has been depleted. It is also cleaner than machine cremation because it does not release ash and pollutants into the air whilst taking up a similar amount of land room. I also believe that people should have access to more funerary options, especially eco-friendly ones.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Ban all disposable plastic bags.
attributes.background: Please completely ban disposable plastic bags from shops and supermarkets and replace them with a paper alternatives at a reasonable price to the customer.
attributes.additional_details: Pollution is a big problem, if we do not do something soon it will be too late to save our planet. I have recently learnt about this and have seen we only have around 6 years to change until the damage we have done is irreversible.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Replace nuclear power with hybrid-solar-battery power in the energy strategy
attributes.background: We the undersigned, want the government to replace monolithic, stagnating nuclear power in the energy strategy with roof-based, modular, sustainable, rapidly evolving hybrid-solar-battery systems and insulation for all social-housing. Batteries will supply baseload power when the sun doesn’t shine.
attributes.additional_details: Installing hybrid-solar-battery systems and insulation for about 4 million social-houses could immediately add an ever-increasing capacity each year, taking less than 5 years to reach full capacity. The power costs less than £44/MWh and could provide over 16 TW baseload per year which could replace about half of current Russian gas energy imports. It could create about 50 thousand long-term service jobs and take-up no extra land. It produces zero pollution from free UK sunlight and, year-on-year, drives down unit costs to grow our green industries and generate more tax revenue. The government could reduce benefits in line with about 50% energy savings in social-housing households to recoup the capital investment in as little as 6 years.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban the sale of plastic lighters in the UK
attributes.background: Pass a law prohibiting the sale and manufacture of plastic lighters, plastic covered lighters and plastic lighter holders in the UK
attributes.additional_details: Millions of tonnes of waste and pollution are created to make disposable and unrecyclable lighters and holders, a simple policy change would at the stroke of a pen prevent this.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Charge companies for improper disposal of products and fly-tipping
attributes.background: 8 million tons of plastic end up in the ocean every year because of improperly disposed products and 11% of all methane in the atmosphere already comes from trash. The law fines people for improper recycling, for fly-tipping, etc, but does not fine companies.
attributes.additional_details:
People cannot bear the full burden of improperly disposed products. 

In USA, companies were being sued by a California environmental group for ‘creating a plastic pollution ‘nuisance’ and misleading consumers about the recyclability of plastic.

It is time the UK to lead the charge against improperly disposed products by ALSO charging companies for their improperly disposed products

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Cancel transport investment and invest in comms etc to encourage home working.
attributes.background: We would like to ask the Government to review and potentially cancel all planned transport investment and instead invest in better communications and business incentives to promote remote/home working.
attributes.additional_details: During the Covid-19 lockdown, there has been a worldwide decrease in pollution levels, probably greater than could possibly achieved any other way. People have worked from home, many probably more productively. Investing in transport may appear to benefit the economy but at what cost? More roads just produce more traffic, more trains mean more people are likely to commute. Homeworking and video communications can remove the vast majority of travel. This would make the UK a world leader in this.

departments.name: Department for International Trade

attributes.action: Allow the sale of nicotine e-liquids in bottles greater than 10 ml.
attributes.background: I would like the government to change the law or regulation that prohibits the sale of nicotine-containing e-liquid in bottles greater than 10ml due to the negative environmental impact this has.
attributes.additional_details: As a society, it is important that we reduce our single-use plastic waste. 5.5% of Britons over the age of 18 vape which means that millions of people are buying e-liquids sold in only 10ml bottles. We would save a lot of plastic waste by allowing people to purchase nicotine-containing e-liquids in bottles greater than 10ml (say 100ml) as this would result in a lower plastic to volume ratio which would result in less plastic waste damaging our environment and polluting our oceans.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Legislate to ban commercial wooden pallets treated with highly toxic chemicals
attributes.background: We ask the Government to ban all commercial wooden pallets which are treated with highly toxic chemicals. There are other eco-friendly pallets available, and there is no justification why any industry should still be using these wooden pallets for logistical transport and distribution.
attributes.additional_details:
People may think wooden pallets are safe to burn domestically, but PM2.5 emissions are one of the most dangerous pollutants to human health. Banning wooden pallets treated with toxic chemicals should benefit the environment, public health and NHS.

More for information see the links below:

https://www.blf.org.uk/sites/default/files/Ambient%20air%20pollution_levelling%20up%20lung%20health.pdf

https://www.london.gov.uk/sites/default/files/pm2.5_in_london_october19.pdf

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Increase Environment Agency funding for environmental protection
attributes.background: Government funding for the Environment Agency’s environmental protection work has fallen from about £170m in 2009-10 to a low of £76m in 2019-20, and £94m last year. I want the overnment to increase funding in this area to 2009-10 levels at least, if not more to address years of low funding.
attributes.additional_details:
The Environment Agency has a large budget but we believe not enough of this is being directed towards protecting or improving the environment.
 
Government grants to the agency rose from £880m to £1.05bn over the past two years, and money for flood operations has steadily increased. But Government funding for the agency’s environmental protection work was £94m last year. Work such as attending pollution incidents must not be deprioritised.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban advertising for new combustion engine vehicles
attributes.background: We need to move to not using combustion engine vehicles as quickly as possible. Vehicle manufacturers need to stop making polluting vehicles.
attributes.additional_details: I think the Government should ban advertising of new internal combustion engine vehicles. This will not stop people buying new cars but it will give Electric vehicles centre stage, perhaps even not taxing advertising for electric vehicles. This would help our country be completely ready for 2030 and be able reduce our emissions more quickly. Putting more electric vehicles on the road sooner will feed the second hand market.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Fund free bus travel for those earning under £15,000 pa
attributes.background: Free bus travel could reduce the need for multiple cars per home.
attributes.additional_details:
Fewer cars per home could also mean fewer cars blocking streets without the need to ban cars from parking anywhere.
 
Fewer cars would mean less pollution.
 
This would particularly help people on low incomes and the unemployed.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Change the speed limit on motorways and dual carriageways
attributes.background: Derestrict the speed limit on UK motorways and dual carriageways. Apply a strict speed limit of 70mph for up to 2 miles on approach of exit, and post entry sections. Enforce strict action against drivers obstructing the flow of overtaking traffic on the right lanes.
attributes.additional_details:
The Government should put in place thorough motoring education and testing system to support such improved UK road network, to upskill UK society to make better drivers.
 
Proposed changes could:
 
Reduce road traffic.
Promote flow of vehicles.
Increase road awareness.
Reduce pollution due to reduced build-up of motor vehicles on roads.
Reduce cost of infrastructure required for average speed monitoring.
Reduce the need for policing thus resulting in savings of public funds.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban plastics in schools
attributes.background: Make a law requiring all schools to stop using plastics and replace them with alternatives.
attributes.additional_details: The current situations regarding pollution from plastics are completely shocking and it should be targeted at schools as they can be one of the biggest plastic polluters in today's society.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Immediate ban on the use of diesel cars and make all public transport free
attributes.background: I want an immediate ban on Diesel engines in the United Kingdom and for public transport to become free.
attributes.additional_details: I want Diesel engines to be banned because they are polluting our earths atmosphere and I think that individual action will not be enough to turn climate change around. Although it may cause some inconvenience there is no point in using the Diesel engines because they are damaging the environment. If you agree me please sign this to create a better earth for our future generations.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Restrict the dates/days and times fireworks can be used.
attributes.background:
Restrict the private use of ‘loud’ fireworks to 3 days before or after 5th November and 31st December unless a licence is obtained.
Restrict fireworks after 11PM with the exception of New Year’s Eve when no fireworks should be set off after 1AM on 1st January.
attributes.additional_details:
I’d like this restriction for the following reasons:
- Fireworks can cause great distress to animals and the elderly. 
- Fireworks are often used by drug dealers to advertise the availability of new stock.
- Fireworks create pollution and the tenements are a danger to property and wildlife.
- Fireworks are more likely to be abused by children/teens if they have a larger window of opportunity to use them.

attributes.action: Stop road closures & no motor vehicle signs that cause congestion & pollution

This causes congestion and additonal pollution on the road system as there is a limited number resources of roads in the road network for use.
attributes.additional_details: We are not against giving priority to other road users/residents/school areas with no vehicles during school times only, but no motor vehicle signs with no school term/time only limit & complete road closures are causing congestion & excessive pollution due to waiting in traffic as there is a very limited number of resources - roads that vehicles can use. rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about the impact of works to build HS2 in the Midlands B46, but it's not clear if you want HS2 to be rerouted or cancelled, or if you want something else to happen.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

Cancel HS2: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/621535
